Distribution and habitat. Tischetkin ( 2013 ) found that the true
Ph. spumarius
was not among specimens he studied from Iran but this appears to be based on only a small sample. According to the published literature (
Dlabola 1957
, 1958 ,
1961 , 1964
,
1967 , 1970
,
1972 , 1981
;
Khajehali et al . 2001
) and the collecting data from our examined material,
Ph. spumarius
is known as a Holarctic faunal element which lives in Steppes with
Astragalus , Semi
steppes, Mesophilic biotopes, at the edge of the forests, bank of rivers with
Juncus
and deciduous shrubs, Hyrcanian vegetation, on
Populus
sp,
Tamarix
, at the edge of snowfields, in orchards (e.g. pomegranate and apple orchards) and fields (e.g. potato, alfalfa and wheat fields).

Ph. spumarius
is a Holarctic species with a wide natural distribution in Europe, Northern Africa, Western Asia, Iran (Northwest, North, center and south,
Fig. 28
), Afghanistan , Central, Northern and Eastern Asia. The publications of records of the localities and the habitats of this species in Iran were all made before the description of
Ph. elbursianus
and
M. iranicus
. Hence the recorded distribution may include these cryptic species too. Specimens recorded by
Mirzayans ( 1995 )
and deposited in the Hayk Mirzayans Insect Museum were examined and corrected but re-identification of specimens from other published records was beyond the scope of this study. The location of examined material is shown with a different colour on the map (
Fig. 28
).
